reviewText:
Following up the delightful and unexpectedly self-aware Unhack, it‚Äôs astonishing how far developer Invert Mouse has fallen with the pitiful Bermuda, an underwater alien thriller that is so dysfunctional I wanted to shut it off to spare it anymore embarrassment.

Invert Mouse‚Äôs main goal with Bermuda seems to be to try something more serious than the developer has done in the past, but rather than settle for conventional drama Bermuda jumps straight into science fiction absurdity. Plot devices are invented off hand and then left suspending in space as if to serve as window dressing for the explosive non sequiturs which cap off each act. It‚Äôs as if in its feverish obsession to create ‚Äúemotional moments‚Äù Bermuda forgets everything that took place before that scene, unconcerned with how far it has vered off course so long as it arrives at the next juicy twist.

But I couldn‚Äôt even find a way to enjoy Bermuda ironically because its flat writing leaves no room for camp or unintended hilarity. Characters are boring, single faceted shells for the equally uninspired plot which drone on and on, unaware that their audience has long since dozed off yet seeming just as bored with their lines. It doesn‚Äôt help that there are a lot of things about Bermuda which are more than a little weird. The religious undertones feel pigeoned in almost for the sake of being able to present Bermuda as a bizarre piece of Christian media, and the fetishistic relationship between two characters left me feeling dirty and creeped out.

It‚Äôs just an immensely unenjoyable experience all around, and one that seems intentionally so but without anything interesting with which to fill the black hole that seems to have enveloped Bermuda to ensure nothing joyful or humorous finds its way in. And so Bermuda comes and goes, full of drama yet lacking any presence and leaving me grasping for even the tiniest justification of the hour I just lost.

reviewText:
Finished the visual novel in one hour, around seven chapters long. There's no save function so my recommendation is to either finish this in one sitting or quit the game - to take a break or do something else - after one chapter finished.

Overall, I can appreciate the voice acting although frankly it's just below average. At least it's something that's often missed when people make VNs.

Gameplay involves some mini games each chapters Stealth B@stard-style. You need to travel undetected to some points mostly using WASD control. I found this to be breaking my pace on reading thru the VNs so three out of six mini games I had them skipped (there's a function to skip the mini games at the top right of the screen).

Character developments are bad. There are five major characters in this VN and only one evolves adequately. Even the main char I found him rambling too much about 'god' to the point I honestly think it's annoying. This char developments correlate directly with the storyline, which is very important for VN. I find it to be rushed also, maybe because of time constraint or whatever. Story is not what I expected it to be. Being a sci-fi, I would hope it contains more, but then the progression is abruptly halted and the game ends prematurely.

Did I say the game's performance is HORRIBLE as well? I have more than decent laptop to run any VNs, yet even on my dedicated graphic card this runs choppily. Bad optimization.

reviewText:
The decision on whether or not to give this a Yes or a No was a hard one; let it be said plainly that I do not think this game is horrible, mainly that it could have been executed much better.

To begin with, it has a lot of grand assets; the art is charming and simple, the sounds are easy to listen to and do not detract from the situation, and as they so prize, the voice acting is very well done.

That's as far as the good goes for me, though; the writing isn't bad by any stretch of the word - not to the extent of bad literature prevalent nowadays, or the plothole-ridden stories common in Visual Novels - it simply isn't driving, and it's hard to see it as something coherent what with the Bonus Conversations pulling you away from the situation to random tidbits about each character. I understand that they wanted to give it to you bit by bit, but the snippets of actual story are rather small, and to have even those few lines included, off-topic and flavorful as they are for the characters, lessens one's understanding of the story and takes away from the impact of presentation. The content of the Bonus Conversations are really just bonus tidbits meant to develop the characters, apparently, and not any actual plot-related content, which would have been more helpful had they not ruined the image cultivated in the story itself.

The minigame they have in between snippets and Acts also seems to be a bit out of place; it's rather simplistic and not intrinsically bad, mind, but it's out of place. It's not a tedious hassle to go through it, and one can finish it without much effort - the problem is that you have to spend time out of the story and into some mechanic-laden minigame.

The analogy I would use for this game's problem is when you're trying to read a book but these small mundane things just keep making you look up and lose where you were in the story - even if you're pausing to answer simple questions or digesting small tidbits.

For its price, I might still venture to get it - but dont expect too much out of it. This is an okay work, but  below the quality I expected from it. Ultimately, my final verdict is that I wouldn't recommend this game; nonetheless, I offer a respectful nod to the developer for making the game.

Overall the game is sub standard, but still enjoyable if you like VN genre. Had it been more expensive, I would have given this a big thumb down. Get this when it's on BIG sale or in a bundle.

reviewText:
Even before diving into this game it was clear that it was done by the same people that made Unhack.
That's not a bad thing though, I quite enjoyed it and was looking forward to a similar experience.
Turns out that was the wrong thing to expect.

Bermuda follows the story of three humans at the beach, Edward, Paul and Joanna, who get kidnapped by strange creatures to be experimented on in their submarine. When I say strange creatures I of course mean cute girls with blue hair and fish bowls over their heads, of course, because we need to hit those anime tropes.

These kidnappings have been going on for decades (inspiring the title of the game), and the creatures want to find out all about 'surfacers' and their strange ways before wiping their memories of the kidnapping and sending them on their way. At the last step of this process something goes wrong. As Joanna is transported back to the surface the teleportation beam unexpectedly breaks, leaving Edward and Paul stuck on the submarine.

Although it was kind of annoying to see the only human girls unceremoniously shoved out of (the majority of) the story it was a nice setup. Over the course of 6 chapters Edward and Paul await their fate, and explore the ship in a very rudimentary stealth game. Don't go expecting something like Gunpoint here, even though this is also a 2D stealth game where you primarily use your environment to solve situations. 'Missions', as the game calls them, are short, <2 minutes short, and there is only one of them in each chapter. I'd complain about that more, but they honestly felt kind of tacked on and lazy so I didn't mind that they weren't a larger element of the game.

Taking all that into account this game would be teetering between a positive and negative recommendation about now.
There is one point that pushed my opinion a long way though, and not in the good direction.

The game's protagonist, Edward, is obnoxiously religious.
This could have been handled as a narrative element, teaching these weird alien abductors what God is or something. I'd probably still not have liked it then, but the way it is now it's just... sort of... there.
This isn't a minor character trait either. Flashbacks of Edward giving Joanna a crucifix, of how he met her at Church, constantly spouting that his faith is being tested or that he prays things will work out.
It's weird, and it utterly spoils all goodwill I had for this game.

Don't get this game unless you think you can handle the wonky religious angle it crammed into it.

The artstyle is very nice for the story, but mediocre for the minigame. The voice acting is very good (which is standard in games).

Ultimately, I recommend you give this a pass--there are far better VNs, even free ones.

The opening premise seemed kind of cool to me, but I barely got halfway through Act 3 before I began to realize how much I disliked or simply was disinterested in nearly all of the cast.

Joanna, in love with Edward, but dating Paul. Extremely disliked. I don't think Eddie could throw religion around any more if he tried, resulting in him being a ridiculously annoying Main, as he's the one whose point of view we're always taking. Paul was probably my favorite character and I'm glad I didn't play through enough of the game to see him eventually get screwed over by his 'girlfriend' and his 'best friend'. Finyomu was okay, but pretty forgettable, and Mukan was shaping up to be a typical tsundere character.

For me, in visual novels the characters have to carry the game, since there's not much else to drive it forward save for the story and how they interact with one another. Of those two, one was just about average, and the other was pretty bad for me in this game.

Bermuda? Completed it mate.

Pros: Cute
Nice art
Plot you can almost care about
7/10 voice acting

Cons: Weird, shakey science that left a lot of unanswered questions, but not ones I really cared much for answering.
Flat in every sense. It felt like something I would have written for a short story competition (and probably lost with).
Short as a motherf-
There's like 20 minutes of gameplay, although it is admittedly clever enough.
God? Religion? What's that about?
Also there was a tiny unnecessary addition of a possible fetishistic relation between two female characters which left me feeling quite.... uncomfortable.

In conclusion, recommend it to burn an ok hour of your life. The way I see it is, it's the price of a shot of tequila, and that's more disgusting than this game, so sort out your priorities.

Sidenote: Plotline has potential if it could be turned into something a bit more powerful and exciting. I like the name.
